A number of regional television networks produce news services. <a href="WIN%20Television">WIN Television</a> produces 20 bulletins in parts of <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>, <a href="Victoria%2C%20Australia">Victoria</a>, <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a>, <a href="South%20Australia">South Australia</a>, and <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a>. <a href="NBN%20Television">NBN Television</a> is the only regional broadcaster to produce a bulletin on both weeknights and weekends, in an hour-long format presented from <a href="Newcastle%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Newcastle</a> and seen across northern <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>. <a href="Prime7">Prime7</a> produces news updates throughout regional New South Wales and Victoria, with sister-network <a href="GWN7">GWN7</a> producing GWN7 News for Western Australia. In the <a href="Northern%20Territory">Northern Territory</a>, <a href="Imparja%20Television">Imparja Television</a> shows <a href="Imparja%20Television%23News">Imparja National News</a>. <a href="Southern%20Cross%20Television">Southern Cross Television</a> produces a bulletin for <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a> and regional South Australia.
Current affairs.
Current affairs programming is shown in a broad range of formats, ranging between <a href="tabloid%20television">tabloid</a>-style current affairs shows to investigative programs such as "<a href="Four%20Corners%20%28Australian%20TV%20program%29">Four Corners</a>".
<a href="ABC%20%28Australian%20TV%20channel%29">ABC</a> has had a long history of producing current affairs programs, including the award-winning "<a href="This%20Day%20Tonight">This Day Tonight</a>", the first regular current affairs program to be shown on Australian television and a training ground for many of Australia's best-known journalists. "This Day Tonight" was axed in 1978, however in the mid-1980s "<a href="The%207.30%20Report">The 7.30 Report</a>" was launched in state-based editions (these were combined into a national program hosted by <a href="Kerry%20O%27Brien%20%28journalist%29">Kerry O'Brien</a> in 1995). "<a href="Four%20Corners%20%28Australian%20TV%20program%29">Four Corners</a>", first seen in 1961, an investigative documentary series modelled on the <a href="BBC">BBC</a>'s "<a href="Panorama%20%28TV%20series%29">Panorama</a>", has also won many awards and broken stories previously not covered by other media outlets.
Other current affairs programs include news and analysis program "<a href="Lateline">Lateline</a>", "<a href="7.30">7.30</a>", "<a href="Foreign%20Correspondent%20%28TV%20series%29">Foreign Correspondent</a>", "<a href="Insiders%20%28Australian%20TV%20program%29">Insiders</a>", "<a href="Offsiders">Offsiders</a>" and "<a href="Australia%20Wide">Australia Wide</a>".
<a href="SBS%20%28Australian%20TV%20channel%29">SBS</a> also shows a number of current affairs programs, such as "<a href="Dateline%20%28Australian%20TV%20program%29">Dateline</a>", the country's longest-running international current affairs program, launched in 1984. "<a href="Insight%20%28Australian%20TV%20program%29">Insight</a>", originally conceived in 1999 as a domestic current affairs program, is a discussion forum focussing on a single issue. SBS's Indigenous Media Unit produces another program titled "<a href="Living%20Black">Living Black</a>", which covers issues relevant to Australia's <a href="Indigenous%20Australians">indigenous</a> community.
There are a number of commercial current affairs programs. The <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a>, in addition to Sunrise, broadcasts "<a href="Today%20Tonight">Today Tonight</a>", a tabloid current affairs program, every weeknight after its 6pm news bulletin. On the <a href="Nine%20Network">Nine Network</a>, "<a href="A%20Current%20Affair%20%28Australian%20TV%20series%29">A Current Affair</a>", first shown in 1971, competes directly with "Today Tonight" and has, since <a href="Ray%20Martin%20%28television%20presenter%29">Ray Martin</a> began presenting in 1994, provided a similar mix of content. On Sundays, "<a href="60%20Minutes%20%28Australian%20TV%20program%29">60 Minutes</a>" features a number of stories produced both locally and from its <a href="60%20Minutes">US counterpart</a>. In the morning "<a href="Sunday%20%28Australian%20TV%20program%29">Sunday</a>" covers local and overseas news, politics, and current affairs, in addition to film reviews, politics, arts, and music.
Political and interview program "<a href="The%20Bolt%20Report">The Bolt Report</a>" is also shown on Sunday mornings, on <a href="Network%20Ten">Network 10</a>.
On <a href="subscription%20television">subscription television</a>, <a href="Sky%20News%20Australia">Sky News Australia</a> airs a number of news commentary and analysis shows such as "Agenda, Sportsline, Sky Business Report, and Sky News Eco Report". A local version of <a href="The%20Weather%20Channel%20%28Australia%29">Sky News Weather Channel</a> was launched in 1999, joined in 2006 by <a href="Fox%20Sports%20News">Fox Sports News</a>, a 24-hour sports news channel. "<a href="Squawk%20Australia">Squawk Australia</a>", a business news program shown from 6.00am, is seen on <a href="CNBC%20Asia">CNBC Asia</a>.
Indigenous television.
In the 21st century, and especially the 2010s, programmes and series by and about <a href="Indigenous%20Australians">Indigenous Australians</a> proliferated. "<a href="The%20Circuit%20%28TV%20series%29">The Circuit</a>" (2007) was an early example; "<a href="Redfern%20Now">Redfern Now</a>", "<a href="8MMM%20Aboriginal%20Radio">8MMM Aboriginal Radio</a>", "<a href="The%20Gods%20of%20Wheat%20Street">The Gods of Wheat Street</a>" (2014), "<a href="Ready%20for%20This%20%28TV%20series%29">Ready for This</a>", "<a href="Cleverman">Cleverman</a>", "<a href="Black%20Comedy%20%28TV%20series%29">Black Comedy</a>", "<a href="The%20Warriors%20%28TV%20series%29">The Warriors</a>", "<a href="Kiki%20%26amp%3B%20Kitty">Kiki & Kitty</a>", "<a href="Total%20Control%20%28TV%20series%29">Total Control</a>", "<a href="KGB%20%28TV%20series%29">KGB</a>", "<a href="Little%20J%20%26amp%3B%20Big%20Cuz">Little J & Big Cuz</a>", "<a href="Mystery%20Road%20%28TV%20series%29">Mystery Road</a>" were all well-received. <a href="Shari%20Sebbens">Shari Sebbens</a> commented that a "golden age" of Indigenous television is here.
The last episode of the second series of "<a href="Get%20Krack%21n%23Series%202%20%282019%29">Get Krack!n</a>", featuring <a href="Miranda%20Tapsell">Miranda Tapsell</a> and <a href="Nakkiah%20Lui">Nakkiah Lui</a> and co-written by Lui, trended on <a href="Twitter">Twitter</a>, outraged right wing commentator <a href="Andrew%20Bolt">Andrew Bolt</a>, and was widely lauded as hilarious, ground-breaking, hard-hitting satire.
<a href="National%20Indigenous%20Television">National Indigenous Television</a> (NITV) is (since 2012) a national, free-to-air channel dedicated to Indigenous stories, news, films and issues, with programming produced largely by Indigenous people, funded through SBS. In early 2016, it refreshed its brand and revamped its schedule, with an increased focus on its central charter, Indigenous news and current affairs.
Ratings.
<a href="Television%20ratings%20in%20Australia">Television ratings in Australia</a> are collected by three main organisations: <a href="OzTAM">OzTAM</a> in metropolitan areas, Regional TAM in regional areas serviced by three commercial <a href="television%20networks">television networks</a>, and in areas with two commercial networks, <a href="Nielsen%20Media%20Research">Nielsen Media Research Australia</a>.
Ratings are collected for 40 weeks during the year, excluding a two-week break during <a href="Easter">Easter</a> and ten weeks over summer. The majority of locally produced comedy and drama on commercial networks is shown during the ratings period.
For many years up until the mid-nineties, the <a href="Nine%20Network">Nine Network</a> had been the ratings leader in Australia, typically followed by the <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> and <a href="Network%20%2010">Network 10</a>. Subscription television and the two national broadcasters, ABC and in particular <a href="SBS%20%28Australian%20TV%20channel%29">SBS</a>, due to its special-interest nature, typically attract fewer viewers than the three commercial networks. Network 10, due to its programming line-up, has traditionally been the market leader for younger viewers.
In 2007, the <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> overtook its rival <a href="Nine%20Network">Nine Network</a> in terms of average viewers, and in 2011, it became the first television network since <a href="OzTam">OzTam</a>'s launch in 2001 to win all 40 weeks in a ratings season. As of 2016, it has won the last ten ratings seasons consecutively. ABC has also, since the early 2000s, seen ratings (as well as audience reach) as a major performance indicator – this has, however, led to a decline in viewers rather than the expected increase. The Nine Network has, in the past, aggressively marketed its long-time ratings dominance through its promotional campaign "Still the One", which they no longer use.
Regulation.
Content on Australian television is regulated by the <a href="Australian%20Communications%20and%20Media%20Authority">Australian Communications and Media Authority</a>. All codes of practice submitted to the Australian Communications and Media Authority are reviewed by the public prior to acceptance. There are different regulations for different types of content, and the main categories are divided up into Australian content, children's content, <a href="commercial%20broadcasting">commercial broadcasting</a>, community broadcasting, <a href="public%20broadcasting">public broadcasting</a>, and <a href="Pay%20TV">subscription television</a>.
The regulations in place define what a broadcaster may put on-air, the time(s) of day they are allowed to broadcast specific material, and what advertisements are shown in relation to these criteria. In essence, the Australian Communications and Media Authority controls what content is shown, what time(s) of day it is shown, and who controls what is shown (i.e.: international media as opposed to <a href="Australian%20media">Australian media</a>).
Genre restrictions imposed by the Australian <a href="Government%20of%20Australia">government</a> on digital multichanneling were lifted along with the media ownership laws passed through the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Australia">Parliament of Australia</a> on 18 October 2006. Digital-only multichannels in Australia were previously limited in the subjects they could cover, with programming identified as comedy, drama, national news, sport or entertainment, prohibited from broadcast.
